noun.description: A remarkable concurrence of events or circumstances without apparent causal connection.
examples: it's no coincidence that this new burst of innovation has occurred in the free nations

noun.description: Correspondence in nature or in time of occurrence.
examples: the coincidence of interest between the mining companies and certain politicians

noun.description: The presence of ionizing particles or other objects in two or more detectors simultaneously, or of two or more signals simultaneously in a circuit.

origin: Early 17th century (in the sense occupation of the same space): from medieval Latin coincidentia, from coincidere coincide, agree (see coincide).
